_exec_summary.SummaryText:
1.  Facility Policy.  The owners, management and employees of Liter Fertilizer and Chemicals are committed to the prevention of any accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia.  If an accidental release should occur, the facility is prepared to work with the local fire department, Marion-Ralls County LEPC, and/or other authorities, to mitigate and minimize the impacts of the release to the public and the environment.

2.  Facility Information.  The primary activity at the facility is the distribution of products to farmers.  The fertilizer product, anhydrous ammonis is received, stored and distributed for direct application as a nutrient for crop production.  Anhydrous ammonia is stored in tanks designed for this purpose.

3.  Accidental Release Prevention Program.  This facility follows the provisions of the U.S. Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA), 29 CFR 1910.111, "Storage and Handling of Anhydrous Ammonia" and our State regulations covering anhydrous ammonia.

4.  Five-Year Accident History. There have been no accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia during the past five years that have caused any deaths, injuries or significant property damage at the facility; nor to our knowlede, has there been any accidental releases resulting in off-site deaths, evacuations, property damage, or environmental damage.

5.  Emergency Response Program.  The facility has a written Emergency Action Plan.  We do not plan to have our employees respond to a major release.  If a large release of anhydrous ammonia takes place at our facility, the response action is to evacuate the area of the release and call 911 and all applicable emergency response numnbers listed in our Emergency Action Plan.

6.  Planned Changes To Improve Safety.  Safety improvement is an on-going process at this facility.  Periodic evalauations are performed to access the conditions of the facility.  There are no specific safety recommendations regarding the storage or the use of anhydrous ammonia f
